description.narrative: This project aims to support the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation and concerned institutions- to establish a coordinated treaty body reporting mechanism and implement activities related to monitoring and reporting of international treaties.
Project to Support Monitoring and Implementation of Treaty Body Reporting in Rwanda.

Building an Inclusive Financial Sector in Rwanda (BIFSIR) Expansion programme aims to contribute to poverty reduction and to the achievement of the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) by promoting inclusive finance and entrepreneurship programs.

title.narrative: Management and Disposal of PCBs in Rwanda

description.narrative: Management and Disposal of Polychlorinated Biphenyls (PCBs) in Rwanda.

title.narrative: Management and Disposal of PCBs in Rwanda

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or sub-national level
Number of men above 15 years of age who acquired new jobs through a UNDP-supported project on NRM, ecosystems services, chemicals and waste
Number of women above 15 years of age who acquired new jobs through a UNDP-supported project on NRM, ecosystems services, chemicals and waste
Total number of people above 15 years of age who acquired new jobs through a UNDP-supported project on NRM, ecosystems services, chemicals and waste
The project aims at reducing environmental and human health risks from Polychlorinated Biphenyls (PCBs) in Rwanda.
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

1) Number of transformers nationwide containing PCB or PCB contaminated fluid 2) Number of tons contaminated with PCB analysed and quantified 3) Number of sites contaminated with PCB identified 4) Number of legal framework to manage PCBs adopted 5) Number of persons trained on health and environmental impacts of PCBs 6) Number of safe PCBs storage facility constructed 7) Number of ton of PCBs contaminated oil and equipment disposed/eliminated.
Minimizing environmental and health risks associated with PCBs though strengthening technical and regulatory capacity for the environmentally sound management and disposal of PCBs in Rwanda

Established and sustainable operational and regulatory capacity undertaking identification and management of PCBs in compliance with Stockholm Convention obligations by 2020
1 Legislation and guidelines adopted 2 Central warehouse with 350 tons of waste 3 Tonnage of PCBs safely disposed

comment.narrative:
NIP adopted based on preliminary knowledge of issue
Absence of implementation capacity either institutionally or physically
Fragmented institutional responsibility for issue
Unsafe poorly located in wetland storage facility for PCBs

Functional regulatory regime covering importexport identification capture and securing PCBs for future disposal
Operation capacity for ESM of current and future stockpiles and waste
Informed PCB holders and qualified service providers to undertake PCB management activities
Clear assignment of responsibilities within the government

PCBs regulatory guidelines aimed at enhancing management and disposal of PCBs in Rwanda have been finalised and adopted by the Government and are now available on the Rwanda Environment Management Authority website
1 Guidelines for inspection monitoring and assessment of PCBs in Rwanda
2 Guideline for mitigation of cross contamination of PCBs oil during the power transformer reparation
3 Guidelines for recycling decontamination and rehabilitation of PCB contaminating equipment oil and sites
4 Guidelines for PCBs inventory
Approved guidelines are now being disseminated to stakeholders for implementation
A PCB Law has been drafted and was validated by the stakeholders The draft law is currently being reviewed by the Rwanda Law Reform Commission before official submission to Ministry of Justice through the Ministry of Natural Resources for enactment by the Parliament The information on when this Draft PCB law will be presented to the Parliament is not available yet
A central warehouse for safe storage of an estimated 500 tonnes of contaminated oil and equipment has been constructed and will be completed by the end of July 2015
On 19th and 20th March 2015 a team from Rwanda that is involved in the implementation of the PCBs project in Rwanda visited Morocco in the framework of SouthSouth Cooperation The mission provided an opportunity for the following 1 Provided a platform for Rwanda and Morocco to learn share information and experiences on management and disposal of PCBs 2 Promoted and strengthened technology transfer best practices and knowledge acquisition between Rwanda and Morocco in addressing technical challenges facing implementation of management and disposal of PCB project in Rwanda 3 Provided an opportunity for the Rwandan project team to learn from counterparts in Morocco on strategies for raising public awareness on PCBs experience on conducting PCB inventory development of PCB legislative frameworks sampling and testing of PCBs private sector engagement legal and technical procedures of procuring a company to eliminate and dispose PCB wastes in approved facilities in Europe as well as meet with technical experts of PCB disposal exporters 4 Enhanced the multiplier effect of technical cooperation amongst developing countries towards implementation of Stockholm Convention on management and disposal of POPs Rwanda is now implementing the recommendations provided by the mission team in order to enhance project delivery

description.narrative: 11 Updated the PCB inventory per category of holders database and reinforced local capacity to maintain and update PCB inventory on annual basis

Detailed inventory of PCB containing and contaminated equipment in service existing PCB waste stockpiles and PCB contaminated sites in place end of 2011
Data management and tracking system operational and used for reporting end of 2011
Supply of lab equipment and consumables for the screening of 1200 units with staff trained in their use by 2011
Technical instructions on identification sampling data management

comment.narrative:
Incomplete inventory of in service equipment and inventories of PCB waste stockpiles cross contaminated equipment and contaminated sites
No formal consolidated PCB information system or associated reporting capability
Absence of capability to costeffectively identify and categorize PCB contaminated materials acting as a major barrier to inventory development and tracking Currently no laboratory is equipped to specifically undertake PCB analysis
No consolidated guidance available to holders of PCBs relevant authorities or service providers on the practical primary management of PCBs

Tracking system for inservice equipment waste stockpiles and contaminated sites that will be maintained on an ongoing basis
Publically accessible PCB information system operational maintained and used for reporting and information exchange under the Convention
One accredited national laboratory capable of doing routine PCB analysis in soil water and air samples inclusive of trained personnel and accessible to responsible regulatory authorities PCB holders and service providers
Screening capacity to effectively support tracking database as PCB management is undertaken into the future
Availability and application of technical instructions for management of current and future PCB inventories and tracking system

The national inventory of 2344 electric transformers completed in 2014 indicated that 293 electric transformers were suspected to contain oil contaminated with PCBs No capacitor was found to be contaminated with PCBs
A total of 61 staff and technicians drawn from Rwanda Energy Group former EWSA REMA and Rwanda Standard Board former Rwanda Bureau of Standard were trained in October 2014 on how to sample and test for PCBs using the ChlorNOil test kits by the national consultant
Using ChlorNOil test kits 461 transformers were tested which included 293 suspected transformer and 168 transformers that were not suspected to confirm the contaminationnoncontamination with PCBs
Results of ChlorNOil tests indicated that 151 transformers of the 293 suspected transformers which approximately weigh 498 tonnes are contaminated with PCBs of more than 50ppm None of the nonsuspicious 168 transformers contained more than 50ppm PCBs
Draft ToR necessary to hire an international consultant to support in quantitative analysis have been developed and are now being reviewed before advertisement can be done by October 2015
The international consultant will provide technical support to the national laboratory of RSB to be able to undertake quantitative analysis of the oil of the 151 PCB containing transformers gt 50 ppm as well as water and soil samples from around leaking transformers that contain PCBs ata concentration of more than 50ppm
The data management tool that was established by updating the 2005 PCB database has been populated with the results of ChlorNOil tests The database provides information about contaminated equipment in operation existing PCB stockpiles and contaminated sites The database will continue to be updated on a regular basis by the Rwanda Energy Group REG limited former EWSA Plans are underway to make the database publicly available in REMA and REG websites once quantitative testing is completed
Assessment of five national laboratories capacities to undertake analysis of PCBs and other POPs chemicals has been done and a report has been prepared in September 2014 The report recommends measures for upgrading the five laboratories capacity to analysis POPsPCBs in different media
A guideline for regular inspection monitoring and continuous updating of the PCBs inventory was produced and printed in 2015 and is being widely disseminated to REG and other PCBs holders

description.narrative: 21PCB legislation and technical guidance developed and implemented

Regulations requiring registration labeling and status reporting of potential all PCB and PCB containing materials in use end of 2010
Adoption of appropriate hazardous waste classification of PCBs and PCB contaminated materials in 2010
Enactment of legal ban on new use reuse trade import and export of PCBs and PCB contaminated equipment and materials in 2010
Legal measures allowing unrestricted regulatory access to information and locations that may have PCBs wastes stockpiles PCB containing equipment and site contamination in 2010

comment.narrative:
No current regulations requiring declarationreportingunique identification by holders of presence of PCB waste stockpiles or PCB containing equipment
PCB waste classification not well defined in current waste management regulations allowing potential avoidance of proper management
No regulation of PCB trade use and importexport
Uncontrolled trade in contaminated PCB equipment occurs including export of stockpiles and waste and import of used PCB equipment
ReUse of PCBs occurs
In appropriate declassification of PCB contaminated equipment occurs
Legal barriers on the ability of authorities to inspect and access sites

A comprehensive national regulatory registry of all PCB containing equipment in service that is maintained and updated such that its status and fate can be tracked
Explicit inclusion of high concentration PCB wastes as priority hazardous wastes in national waste management legislationregulations
Consistency of these with applicable international standards and the Basel Convention on transboundary movement of hazardous waste
Effective implementation and enforcement of use reuse trade import and export bans including ensuring trade in scrapped contaminated PCB equipment and import of used PCB equipment is eliminated
Allowance in practice of access by mandated regulatory authorities to sites potentially containing or contaminated by PCBs including rights to initiate assessment

A PCBs Law which provides the legal framework for the management disposal and phaseout of PCBs in Rwanda in line with Basel and Stockholm Conventions provisions and requirements has been developed and validated by the stakeholders
The draft PCB law is currently being reviewed by the Rwanda Law Reform Commission before official submission to Ministry of Justice through the Ministry of Natural Resources for enactment into a law by the Parliament
The draft PCB law defines legislation on appropriate hazardous waste classification of PCBs and PCB contaminated materials enactment of legal ban on new use reuse trade import and export of PCBs and PCB contaminated equipment and materials legal measures allowing unrestricted regulatory access to information and locations that may have PCBs wastes stockpiles PCB containing equipment and site contamination

description.narrative: 22 Developed and established rules to avoid crosscontamination of the oils and equipment rulesprocedures on handling contaminated oilsequipment and labeling

Legal measures related to the reuse of PCB oil and PCB contaminated mineral oil transformers
Legal measures on the handling transport of dangerous chemical substances

comment.narrative:
No regulation on use and reuse of PCB oil and PCB contaminated mineral oil
No regulation for handling and transport of dangerous substances

Mitigation of cross contamination
Mitigation of risks of leakage and PCB pollution during transport and handling

The following PCB guidelines have been developed validated by the stakeholders and adopted by the Government in December 2014
1 Guidelines for mitigation of cross contamination of PCBs oil during the power transformer reparation
2 Guidelines for recycling decontamination and rehabilitation of PCB contaminating equipment oil and sites
3 Guidelines for inspection monitoring and assessment of PCBs in Rwanda
4 Guidelines for PCBs inventory
The guidelines have been shared on the PCB portal of REMA website

description.narrative: 31 Public awareness campaigns conducted

Publically accessible information on PCBs and their management including i a maintained official web site iia widely distributed brochure iii media exposure two annual campaigns during project iv information events two during project
Educational curricula related to chemicals including PCBs impacts on environment and human health and management actions for addressing the issue during the project
Training and information seminars on chemicals management including PCBs for relevant government agencies the academic community affected communities NGOs and holders of PCBs 22 workshops

comment.narrative:
Low level of general awareness related to PCBs and chemicals management generally across all stakeholders
No current information products or programs
Limited active educational efforts or tools available
Key stakeholders generally have limited awareness of the issue or actions required of them to address it

Widely accessible current information on PCBs and ongoing management activities
Integration into a national information program on sound chemicals management
Inclusion of chemicals management and particularly PCBs in relevant educational programs and active RD interest in addressing it
Well informed stakeholder community engaged in addressing the issue with a high level of understanding and technical capacity

REMA has produced a capacity building plan to raise public awareness of the environmental and health effects of exposure to PCBs
A training manual and information dissemination materials posters brochures and flyers for raising awareness about the health and environmental effects of exposure to PCBs have been developed and are now being disseminated in ongoing public awareness campaigns All downloadable tools will be made available on the REMA web site
During this reporting period the following workshopsseminars have taken place
1 A training of 32 journalists from 32 different media houses Nov 2014
2 A training of 30 District Environmental facilitators 25 representatives from REG Ltd 5 REMA staff from the Department in charge of Environmental regulation and pollution control as well as a representative from RSB Oct 2014
3 14 training sessions in 14 secondary schools in which 710 students and teachers 390 55 male and 320 45 female across Western Northern and Southern provinces were trained in June 2015
4 A training of 55 staff from 55 NGOs dealing with Environment and Natural Resources across Rwanda were trained in JuneJuly 2015
REMAs department of environmental education and mainstreaming is currently spearheading the review of the education curriculum to ensure that environmental issues are incorporated in primary and secondary education Chemicals management including PCBs and POPs are some of the new topics that will be proposed
Collaboration between REMA and institutions of higher learning through this project has enhanced sensitization on POPsPCBs among teaching staff Institutions of higher learning are actively participating in the project steering committee and in the project technical team This has contributed towards the department of Chemistry at University of Rwanda integrating sessions on POPs and PCB management in existing courses and recommending the review of the curriculum on dynamic equilibrium for fourth year degree students to include Sustainable Chemical Management including POPsPCBs

description.narrative: 32 Promoted safe and proper equipment handling at holders holders trained on leak handling safeguarding and repairing of olddamaged equipment

Strategy and plan for pretreatment and disposal of PCB stockpiles and wastes in place end of 2011
Development of standards and methodologies for ongoing identification and assessment of contaminated sites inclusive of RECO staff to undertake it
Long term plan for the monitoring in place and phase out of PCB containing equipment in service consistent with Convention requirements 2025 formally adopted
Technical guidance and training available for handling transport and safeguarding

comment.narrative:
No plan in place to develop or access pretreatment or disposal capacity exists for PCB waste stockpiles
No capacity exists respecting contaminated site clean up generally and specifically with respect to PCB contamination
The phase out of PCB equipment is currently uncontrolled and includes practices such as sellingexporting PCB contaminated equipment for scrap importing used PCB equipment for new or replacement installations and replacing PCB oils in transformers to declassify the equipment
No technical capacity available for handling transport and safeguarding in the country

Comprehensive strategy and plan adopted defining selection and the process of implementation of pretreatment and disposal options both to be applied in the country ie equipment decontamination soil management potential cement kiln utilization and through export including potential regional initiatives
Operational capability within responsible government agencies andor commercial service providers to undertake assessment and cleanup of PCB contaminated sites consistent with international practice
A fully elaborated detailed plan endorsed by responsible authorities and PCB holders for replacement of in service PCB equipment identified in the detailed national inventory Outcome 1 consistent with Convention obligations
Secure PCB handling transport storage operations

Methodologies for continuous assessmentmonitoring identification sampling and testing of suspected contaminated sites oils and equipment have been included in the following guidelines that have been produced and approved by the Government in December 2014
1 Guidelines for mitigation of cross contamination of PCBs oil during the power transformer reparation
2 Guidelines for recycling decontamination and rehabilitation of PCB contaminating equipment oil and sites
3 Guidelines for inspection monitoring and assessment of PCBs in Rwanda

description.narrative: 41 Assessed existing locations for safe PCB equipment storage 42 Collected PCB equipment packaged oils and waste sent for storage locations

Secure storage capacity for PCB stockpiles and wastes at RECO sites for PCB material and PCB wastes by end of 2012
Operational rules for handling and transport adopted by RECO management

comment.narrative:
No hazardous waste storage suitable for PCB waste stockpiles is available
No provision for secure storage at holders sites
No handling equipment and secure transport infrastructure available

1 national designated secure storage facility established in RECO premises and equipped with necessary infrastructure for PCB waste stockpiles under continuing care and custody of a responsible government authority
Major holders have secure storage facilities to accommodate PCB contaminated equipment when retired as an option
Mitigation of risks associated with handling and transport of PCBs

A central warehouse for safe storage of an estimated 500 tonnes of contaminated oil and equipment has been constructed and will be completed by end of July 2015
This warehouse is built on a land owned by REG which is adjacent to a new power plant of the same company This land had become unfit for living after the power plant has been built particularly because of the noise coming for this power plant and REG had organised expropriation of some inhabitants on that field and either relocation or financial compensation as per Rwandas laws had been provided It is important to note that this action happened prior to the allocation of this land for the PCB project and was not linked to it no social grievance was reportedgenerated
REG Ltd which is the institution in charge of maintaining all electric transformers in Rwanda both public and privately owned will ensure safe storage of all Pure PCBAskarel and PCBs contaminated oil those in store and after decommissioning those in use in the central warehouse before being dechlorinated or disposed of at approved facilities

description.narrative: 43 Agreed disposal plan put in place shipment overseas and final disposal

Trained and equipped service providers capable of undertaking packaging transportation end of 2010
Residual contamination cleanup for PCB solid wastes including training of RECO staff by end of 2010
Feasibility assessment and decision respecting cleaning of PCB containing equipment to allow recycling of metallic scraps
Disposal of 150 MT of PCB stockpiles by export to a qualified disposal facility by 2012
Safety storage of 350 tons of solid wastes until recycling

comment.narrative:
Limited trained capability in the safe handling of PCB contaminated materials and general absence of such capability among holders of PCBs and private service providers
Some PCB containing electrical equipment transformers are in critical applications and have long remaining service lives
Current practices involving replacement of oil do not meet international standards and result in retention of PCB contaminated equipment
No identified and secured stockpiles with most stockpiles likely being exported as scrap but leaving residual contamination in the form of waste materials and contaminated soils at unknown locations
No assigned responsibility for hazardous waste management generally and PCBs in particular

Fully operational service provider capacity to support the securing of PCB waste stockpiles and transport to the designated national facility or export for disposal
Establish the feasibility of environmentally sound transformer decontamination locally as an option to replacement and export of large volumes of materials for ESM disposal
Environmentally sound disposal of 150 MT of PCB oil and PCB contaminated mineral oil and local experience for future disposal requirements

REMA has requested UNDP to directly implement the activity related to elimination and disposal of PCBs contaminated oil and equipment in Rwanda UNDP is therefore in the process of hiring an international consultant to provide technical support and advice on the best methods for elimination and disposal of pure PCBs Askarel crosscontaminated PCBs oil and PCB contaminated soil and equipment in Rwanda The international consultant will also support in tender documents preparation procurement evaluation and contract management of a transportationdisposal company to undertake elimination and disposal of PCBs
The consultant will also provide advice and technical support to UNDP during hiring of a company to potentially undertake dechlorination of PCBs contaminated oil containing less than 10000ppm as well as the disposal of high content PCB oils Askarel at an approved facility before the end of the project

description.narrative: Outcome 12 RECO principal PCB holder and other possible holders are accessed to establish partnership schemes for earlymature equipment replacement

Phase out program and disposal plan established by the end of 2011
Purchase of new transformers

comment.narrative: Phase out criteria limited to electricity supply and economical parameters

Availability and application of technical instructions for management of current and future PCB inventories and tracking system
Reco staff technically able to manage disposal plan

An international consultant is being hired to review and improve the draft PCBs management and national disposal plan for the phasingout of PCB oil and contaminated equipment that has been developed by a national consultant in September 2014

For others such as ICT.

description.narrative: 1) Functional integrated case management system 2) Level of access to justice by citizens 3) Strengthened capacity of the prosecution 4) Percentage of reports submitted timely by national actors as required by human rights bodies 5) Number of CSOs participating in the parallel reporting;

comment.narrative: 1) None (MINIJUST 2013) 2) 67.18% (RGS 2012) 3) 67% 4) 2 CSOs (MINIJUST 2013)
1) 3rd milestone of the Integrated Electronic Case Management System completed (IECMS Modules and software development). 2) 81% 3) 0 4) 100% 5) 25 CSOs

1)The 3rd and 4th milestones have been completed consisting of the development of IECMS modules for the justice institutions as well as the development of the IECMS software. The project management team has also been trained and will train other users. 2) The level of access to justice by citizens has improved, scoring 80.25% in the latest Rwanda Governance Scorecard which was released in 2015. 3) No prosecutors trained in 2015 4) 100% - All due reports to Treaty Bodies and UPR have been submitted at 100% 5) 25 CSOs participated in the preparation of their shadow report for the 2015UPR review for Rwanda.

1) The Integrated Electronic Case management system operational 2) 90 Access to Justice Bureaus officials trained on legal practice 3) 28 prosecutors and judicial police officials trained 4) 100% of TBR due reports submitted on time 5) 5 CSO participating in parallel reporting

1. The system entered in its 2nd phase . It’s operational in 20 primary courts, 12 intermediate courts, 4 High Court and 1 Commercial High Court, 3 Commercial Courts and at the Supreme Courts. 31 out of 454 Police Stations are using the system, 33 NPPA office out of 73, 6 RCS out of 15. Briefly the system is scaled countrywide where the internet connection is available and the second phase is expected to be completed by end 2017 if funds available. 2. all 90 MAJ were trained on legal practice, and on other topics, 30 MAJ Coordinators were trained on the use of IECMS and 60 MAJ in charge of GBV and Judgment execution were trained on Human rights in particular on Civil and Political rights in Q2. 3. 28 Prosecutors and Judicial police were trained on investigation and prosecution of international crimes. 4. The only report which was due in 2016 was on the Convention against Torture and its protocols, it was submitted in June 2016. 5.2 Workshops with CSos were organized, one on the roapmad of UPR recommendations implementations, and the other one on CAT report before its submission.

description.narrative: 1) Number of CSOs participating in human rights monitoring; 2) Level of timely submission of reports on human rights against the number required by UN bodies 3) Number of studies / assessment conducted to influence policies 4) Harmonized system for reporting on human rights violations 5) Number of partners and staff benefiting from capacity building initiatives

comment.narrative: Baseline 1) 2 CSOs (2013) 2) 67% r (RGS 2012) 3) 0 (2013) 4) No harmonized system in place 5)0
1) 5 CSOs. 2) 100% 3) 3 studies 4) The harmonized system is fully utilized 5) 450

1.5 CSOs participated in the monitoring of human rights especially the assessment of the level of implementation of Concluding observations from UN treaty bodies on 2 reports submitted by Rwanda on CAT and CWM and the Survey with CSO’s and media on the implementation of UPR recommendations: 2.100% - All required reports on human rights have been submitted 3.5 studies including assessment of the level of implementation of Concluding observations from UN treaty bodies, the Survey with CSO’s and media on the implementation of UPR recommendations, the Survey on the impact of NCHR’s and other oversight institutions recommendations on national policies, the survey on the application of international labour standards in the Private Sector in Rwanda, and the Survey on GBV (rape on minors). 4.The harmonized system for reporting by human rights monitoring institutions is fully utilized, especially the office of the ombudsman and the national Commission for human Rights. 5.450
1) 5 CSOs participating in human rights reporting in 2016 2) 100% due reports in 2016 submitted on time 3) 2 studies/assessments conducted in 2016 4) No target in 2016 5) 235 people trained in 2016

1) 8 CSOs participated in human rights reporting in 2016 2) 100% of due TBR have submitted on time 3) 6 studies / assessments have been conducted (CRC and its 2 Protocols, ICESCR, CAT and CMW) 4) 587 people trained in human human rights in 2016, focusing on how to report on human rights violations. Commissioners and staff of the National Commission for human Rights also were trained in results based planning and monitoring and gender mainstreaming.

description.narrative: Provide technical and financial support to key national and community actors to promote dialogue, mediation, peace, security, unity and reconciliation processes
capital of a political entity
1) % of citizens satisfied with reconciliation, social cohesion and unity mechanisms 2) Number of knowledge products produced on reconciliation 3) Number of new reconciliation initiatives established

comment.narrative: 1) 83.57% (RGS2012) 2)1 Reconciliation Barometer Report (RRB 2010) 3) 1
1) 72.5 % 2) 1 (Reconciliation Barometer) 3) 1 (Youth Parliamentarians forum)

1) 80.58 % (The Rwanda Governance Scorecard 2014). Note: The Score card introduce new parameters in measuring social cohesion and unity and reconciliation, which brought down the 2014 score to 80.58% from 83.57% in 2012. The new Reconciliation barometer scored this indicator at 92.1% (Dec 2015). 2) 1 (The 2nd reconciliation barometer has been produced a s planned) 3) 1 (The Youth Parliamentarian forum has been organized on the International Day of Peace, bringing together 300 youth from all around the country in order to share their views on peace building and initiatives of the youth in Rwanda with policy makers and civil society leaders.
1) 92.5 % 2) 1 Road-map for the implementation of the findings from the 2015 Reconciliation Barometer 3) Reconciliation barometer findings disseminated to various forums at community level

1) 92.5 % 2) The roadmap fror the implementation of 2015 RRB has been completed 3) The reconciliation barometers findings were discussed in various forums where 683 leaders (280 women and 403 men) from 30 districts including mayors of districts, executive secretaries of sectors, religious leaders, NGOs, national and international leaders and other key partners on unity and reconciliation discussed the Reconciliation status and suggested and recommended solution to the challenges. At national level, 321 participants from different institutions attended and discussed on the Rwanda reconciliation Barometer findings, 201 were men and 120 women.

description.narrative: Advancing and Sustaining Gender Equality Gains in Rwanda is a joint programme between the National Gender Machinery and the One UN in Rwanda.
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - social services (incl youth development and women+ children)

1. Harmonized gender capacity building plan 2. % of National Gender Machinery recommendations developed and submitted for adoption 3. Number of sectors with a gender strategy 4. Number of ministries with gender budget statements 5. Timely submission of national reports on gender.

comment.narrative: 1. 2 new districts with gender sector strategy 2. 30 districts, 14 ministries with gender budget statement 3. 75 % of FFRP members benefited from an induction course , 40 MPs, 21 planners and 14 chief trained in Gender Responsive Budgeting, 4. 4 gender mainstreaming policy briefs/guidelines developed 5. 5 national, 2 international dialogues/events on gender equality and GBV organized 6. 3 sectors and 10 districts with gender profiles

1. The Ministry of Gender and Family Promotion (MIGEPROF)has developed gender strategy for 2 sectors of activities: Private Sector and Local government. Both strategies have been validated by stakeholders but they are still waiting for approval by the MIGEPROF and its partners Ministry of Local Government (MINALOC) and Private Sector Federation. 2. 30 districts and all ministries have developed their gender budget statements for 2014-2015 and 2015-2016 fiscal years 3. Fifty (50) new Parliamentarians members of the Rwanda Women Parliamentary Forum (FFRP) were equipped with required knowledge to play oversight role with gender lens. The knowledge acquired enabled the Members of Parliament to analyze and pass gender sensitive bills and budget starting with the 2014/15 national budget and gender budget statement approval. Over 14 Chief budget managers, 21 planners and budget officers, 28 district staff in charge of gender and family promotion enhanced their skills in gender responsive budgeting through a five day training on Gender Responsive Budgeting. It is expected that the skills acquired will facilitate them to address gender related issues in national and district planning and budgeting processes. This training also contributed to the improvement of the quality of the 2015-2016 Gender budget statement. 4. 3 gender mainstreaming policy briefs/guidelines were developed: GBV Monitoring Guidelines were produced and shared with the CSOs by Gender Monitoring Office (GMO); the Parent’s evening (Umugoroba w’Ababyeyi) guidelines reviewed; and the Family’s Performance Contract (IMIHIGO) notebook produced. 5. 7 national and 3 international events on gender equality and GBV have been organized; these are: national events: the National Women Leaders’ Summit by Ministry of Gender and family Promotion (MIGEPROF); the Dialogue on better coordination and effectiveness of women’s empowerment initiatives at provincial level by the Forum for Women Parliamentarians (FFRP), the D
1. 3 new gender sector strategies 2. 30 districts and 15 ministries with gender budget statements 3. 15 districts with gender profiles

1. 7 existing gender sector strategies: Agriculture, Private Sector, RNP Gender policy, Local Government, women and youth access to finance strategy, capacity building, Girls education policy. Infrastructure has just started developing one. 2. All districts and ministries did gender budget statements for 2016/2017 and also produced implementation reports for 2015/2016 as per the provisions of the law 3. 25 districts have gender profiles

1. The programme will support to enhance the capacity of PM office 2. the 30 Districts by training/coaching the staffs in the mainstreaming of the Monitoring and Evaluation framework during monitoring of government policies and programmes. 3. Support to promote investments and resources mobilization by 10% in the 30 Districts and in Rwanda Development 4. Board (RDB) will be enhanced. 5. A National Qualification and Competency Framework for Rwanda that will enhance coordination of activities of programmes related to capacity building initiatives will be established by National Capacity 6. Building Secretariat (NCBS). 7. Efforts to comprehensively review the Rwandan capital market development will be enhanced through drafting of project legislation and tax framework to support in the financial sector development through Ministry of Finance.

1. An Evaluation National policy at the Prime Ministers' office has been drafted. 2. District coaches supported the review and improvement in the quality of the Districts annual plans and budgets for the financial year 2015/2016. 3. Communications and advocacy strategy for the National Statistical System (NSS) The ICT technical advisor at National Institute of Statistics (NISR). 4. project dubbed ‘Building a Regional Business and Financial Centre for Eastern and Central Africa’ has been developed in Ministry of Finance and Economic Planning (MINECOFIN). 5. Investment experts at RDB mapped potential investors and branding Rwanda as an investment and tourism destination.
